bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Henry Rose Carter, April 5, 1923

div1.p: Howard provides information to Carter on appropriate Latin terms used to reference the “yellow fever mosquito.”

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Henry Rose Carter, April 5, 1923
div1.opener:
Howard
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE,
BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY,
WASHINGTON, D. C.
April 5, 1923.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have yours of the 3rd, and am returning the two en-
closures. You are a very careful man to have come to the Bureau
and looked up aegypti. Most people would have taken my word for
it.

I don't like to think that you will continue in your book
the use of the expression “the Stegomyia” as a vernacular name
for the yellow fever mosquito. If you don't like “A. aegypti,”
why don't you refer to it simply as “the yellow fever mosquito?”
That is what I have done in my lectures and in the few articles
I have written recently.

As to your non-use of aegypti because it is a genitive form
and not a nominative form, the reason becomes ineffective when
we consider (and this is the general view held by nearly all
systematic zoologists) that a name is a name after it has once
been established, no matter what its derivation may have been.
We refer to the specific name as representing a definite thing,
that is, the species; and we stick in the generic abbreviation
simply to fix it more closely, especially with a specific name
which is commonly used in different families and genera, such
as “fuscus” or “alba” or “viridis.” If I were you, I would
simply use the term “yellow fever mosquito” after having fully
2.--Dr. Carter.
explained in the beginning that the yellow fever mosquito is
now known as Aäedes (Stegomyia) aegypti L.; or, if you wish to
appear more scientific, occasionally vary it with “A. aegypti.”
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L. O. Howard Chief of Bureau.
loh-wft
Enclosures.
P. S. I am very sorry that I missed you when you called
at this office on April 3rd.
